title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour

snippet: Soon afterwards we reached what was called theScotch Dyke, the name given to a mound of earth, or "dyke," as it wascalled locally, some four miles long and erected in the year 1552between the rivers Esk and Sark to mark the boundary between England andScotland.

title: Rambles in Europe:

title: The captain of the guard.

title: The captain of the guard.

snippet: ** Say not so, after our late glorious victory at Sark 1 " exclaimed the chancellor ; " but, nevertheless, I have evil news," he added, taking from the velvet pouch which hung at his embroidered girdle several letters, folded square, and tied with ribbons, in the fashion of the time.

title: The captain of the guard.

title: The captain of the guard.

title: A Traveller's Notes, in Scotland, Belgium, Devonshire, the Channel Islands, the Mediterranean, France, Somersetshire, Cornwall, the Scilly Isles, Wilts, and Dorsetshire, in 1866. [By H. G.]
author: G., H.
snippet: We returned past RouezPoint, from whence Guernsey, Sark, and Alderney, areclearly seen, and then inland through St. Mary's andSt. Lawrence's, two pretty little villages, where the sceneryis much more garden-like, and the soil more fertile.

title: A Traveller's Notes, in Scotland, Belgium, Devonshire, the Channel Islands, the Mediterranean, France, Somersetshire, Cornwall, the Scilly Isles, Wilts, and Dorsetshire, in 1866. [By H. G.]
author: G., H.
snippet: Two men, with whom I had made friends overnight, nowcame on deck, one evidently a swell, who talked of his yacht,and urged me to land at Guernsey and have a few days fishingwith him; and the other a man also up in yachting, but on ahumbler scale, who seemed well acquainted with the islands,and kept me amused for some time in talking about them,pointing out Jeppo (I think he called it), between Guernseyand Sark, where the Clergyman, the only Gentleman in theisland—the total number of inhabitants being less than 300—and who, having once been shipwrecked, has made up hismind never to quit terra firma again.
